title: Mum had no idea ‘funny’ tasting wine was first sign of heart attack
text:
Mother-of-two Louise McGill was terrified she was going to die when she realised she was having a heart attack (Picture: ncjMedia Ltd)

When a mother had a sip of wine and thought it tasted funny, she assumed it was a bad bottle but little did she know it was actually the first sign of a heart attack.

Louise McGill, from Waterhouses, County Durham, thought nothing of the seemingly off wine until she woke up in the night with agonising chest pains.

The mother of twin daughters, who was then 45, was terrified she was going to die when paramedics told her she was having a heart attack.

Now Louise, 47, is trying to raise awareness of women’s early symptoms of heart attacks so more can act quickly.

She said: ‘The first sign that something wasn’t right was when I had a glass of wine and it tasted really funny.

‘My husband tried some too and said it was fine, so I didn’t think much of it.

‘That night, I woke up just after midnight with excruciating pain and pressure in my chest.

Louise thought she was just exhausted from being a busy working mum (Picture: ncjMedia Ltd)

‘At first I thought it might be indigestion but I quickly realised that something wasn’t right and my husband called an ambulance.

‘When the paramedics arrived they said they thought I was having a heart attack. I looked at my husband and just started sobbing.

‘I guess I was in shock and my first thought was that I was going to die.’

Louise was rushed to the Freeman Hospital, in Newcastle, and had a stent fitted into her left coronary artery.

As soon as she had the surgery, Louise said she ‘immediately’ began to feel better, adding: ‘I couldn’t believe it was that quick. The surgeon said there is a second blockage in my other artery, but it’s not big enough to need a stent’.

Louise is urging other women to prioritise their heart health from a young age, as she feels many women think a heart attack won’t happen to them.

Now she has had time to reflect, Louise said in the week leading up to the heart attack she was falling asleep on the sofa as soon as she got home from work, which was unusual for her.

Louise is urging women to look out for the early signs (Picture: ncjMedia Ltd)

But the busy working mum thought she’d just ‘hit a wall’ juggling the pressures of life and staying late at work, adding: ‘Which I realise now is a typical female response.’

She said: ‘Women I meet at work and socialising don’t always know the warning signs of a heart attack.

‘I had extreme tiredness before mine, but thought it was just because I was busy. I am more conscious of how I eat and what I eat now.

‘I try not to take on too much anymore and don’t work as long hours.’

Louise is raising awareness of the symptoms she suffered as the British Heart Foundation (BHF) launches a new briefing, which reveals stark inequalities in awareness, diagnosis and treatment of heart attacks that are killing women in the UK.

Its new research shows women often delay seeking medical help by more than two hours, reducing their chance of survival, as many see heart attacks as a ‘man’s disease’.

More than 8,200 women in England and Wales alone died over a 10-year period because they did not receive equal treatment to men.

Dr Sonya Babu-Narayan, Associate Medical Director of the British Heart Foundation, said heart attacks have never been so treatable.

She added: ‘Yet women are dying needlessly because heart attacks are often seen as a man’s disease, and women simply don’t receive the same standard of treatment as men.

‘The studies detailed in this briefing have revealed inequalities at every stage of a woman’s medical journey, and though complex to dissect, they add up to a societal failure to provide fair care for women. Together, we must change this.’

Advertisement

Dr Babu-Narayan added that the assumption women are not at risk of a heart attack is ‘false and has proven to be deadly’.

She added: ‘The BHF wants to empower women to better understand their risk and to know the many symptoms of a heart attack.

‘When someone has a heart attack – every second counts. The sooner people recognise their symptoms and call 999, the better their chance of recovery’.

description: Louise McGill, from Waterhouses, County Durham, is raising awareness of the symptoms of a heart attack in women.
